# Matrix Inverse

At the end of the last chapter, we found that for a Markov chain with
transition matrix P and stationary distribution $\nu$,

$$
\nu = P \nu
$$

This suggests a method for computing $\nu$, by solving the above
equation.

Rewrite it using the identity matrix:

$$
(I - P) \nu = 0
$$

For the random walk chain in Chapter 1, we had

$$
P =
\left (
\begin{array}{rrrrr}
0.5 & 0.5 & 0 & 0 & 0\\
0.5 & 0 & 0.5 & 0 & 0\\
0 & 0.5 & 0 & 0.5 & 0\\
0 & 0 & 0.5 & 0 & 0.5\\
0 & 0 & 0 & 0.5 & 0.5 \\
\end{array}
\right )
$$

With $\nu = (\nu_1,\nu_2,\nu_3,\nu_4,\nu_5)'$, the equation to be solved
is

$$
\left (
\begin{array}{rrrrr}
0.5 & -0.5 & 0 & 0 & 0 \\
-0.5 & 0 & -0.5 & 0 & 0 \\
0 & -0.5 & 0 & -0.5 & 0 \\
0 & 0 & -0.5 & 0 & -0.5 \\
0 & 0 & 0 & -0.5 & 0.5 \\
\end{array}
\right )
\left (
\begin{array}{rrrrr}
\nu_1 \\
\nu_2 \\
\nu_3 \\
\nu_4 \\
\nu_5 \\
\end{array}
\right ) 
\left (
\begin{array}{rrrrr}
0 \\
0 \\
0 \\
0 \\
0 \\
\end{array}
\right ) 
$$
